metadata.title: A Closer Look At Dataset Columns. A look at a dataset’s columns and other… | by Adam Ross Nelson | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: A Closer Look At Dataset Columns
metadata.description: Researchers and data scientists work with datasets. Datasets are the raw material. When we apply analytical techniques to this raw material we produce summaries, tabulations, estimates, and other…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: I’ve previously explained that a dataset consists of rows and columns.
The Art of Effective Visualization of Multi-dimensional Data

all_paragraphs: Researchers and data scientists work with datasets. Datasets are the raw material. When we apply analytical techniques to this raw material we produce summaries, tabulations, estimates, and other output.
I’ve previously explained that a dataset consists of rows and columns. In the course of conducting our work we sometimes also refer to columns as dimensions or variables.

Swapping and interchanging these terms (columns, dimensions, variables, etc.) can lead to confusion. This article seeks to clarify that confusion by showing how and why we sometimes use other terms such as dimensions or variables instead of columns.

This article demonstrates its key terms and phrases with a data set known as the auto dataset, provided by Stata Corporation who are the makers of the popular Stata statistical programming software. Figure 1 shows an expert of this dataset.
Assuming you have a Python configuration that includes Pandas, you can produce similar output with the following three lines of code:
To begin understanding why we sometimes use the term dimension interchangeably to refer to a dataset’s column, look at Figure 2.

Figure 2 is a scatter plot of the variables miles per gallon (mpg, along the vertical y axis) and weight (weight, along the horizontal x axis). A scatter plot is a way to visualize, in graphical form, the relationship between two variables.

When visualized as a graph this figure, or any scatter plot, demonstrates how the y and x variables correspond to a graph's y and x dimensions. This is why researchers and data scientists sometimes refer to a dataset columns interchangeably as dimensions.

To further illustrate, sometimes we want to add a third, fourth… or kth dimension. Figure 3 shows a scatter plot of the variables miles per gallon (mpg, along the vertical y axis) and weight (weight, along the horizontal x axis) and length (length, along the other horizontal z axis).

This visualization technique can assist in illustrating the relationship between these three variables. Beyond three dimensions, however, it gets difficult to visualize. But, in this case, there is technically a fourth dimension. The dotted colors represent that fourth dimension. In this case blue for foreign makes, and yellow for domestic makes.

To further cope with additional dimensions, a variety of statistical techniques are available which can derive an equation that summarizes this multi-dimensional (aka, multi-variate) relationship. The summarization is typically expressed in the form of an equation.
This equation form turns to explain why columns, which are synonymous with dimensions, are also synonymous with variables.
Look at these equations, to begin understanding why we sometimes use the term variables interchangeably to refer to a dataset’s column.

These two equations summarize the relationships shown in figures 2 and 3. Equation 1 indicates that for each additional pound of vehicle weight, miles per gallon will decrease by .0060 miles per gallon.
Again returning to the graphical examples above, this equation can be graphed on y and x dimensional coordinates. Such a line would look like the one shown in Figure 4, here.

Showing how the relationships between these columns, or dimensions, can be summarized as mathematical equations illustrate why we also sometimes refer to a dataset’s columns as variables. As a convention, when in equation form, it is customary to refer to these constructs as variables.

This article discussed why we sometimes interchangeably refer to a dataset’s columns as dimensions or as variables. In doing so, this article also demonstrated scatter plots as an analytical technique that can help understand the relationship between two or more variables.
Credit: Three-dimensional visualization inspired by @Dipanjan (DJ) Sarkar The Art of Effective Visualization of Multi-dimensional Data.
